snippet: Instead, the Kremlin used the results, which indicated overwhelming support for secession from Kiev, to press for some manner of negotiated autonomy.
abstract: Russia stops short of outright recognition of contentious referendums organized by separatists in Donetsk and Luhansk, Russian-speaking provinces of southeast Ukraine; instead uses results to intensify pressure for negotiated autonomy for those provinces.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by David M. Herszenhorn from Moscow, Andrew E. Kramer from Donetsk, Ukraine; Alan Cowell from London; Alison Smale from Berlin; Noah Sneider from Slovyansk, Ukraine; and Andrew Higgins and James Kanter from Brussels.

lead_paragraph: Instead, the Kremlin used the results, which indicated overwhelming support for secession from Kiev, to press for some manner of negotiated autonomy.

headline.main: Russia Keeps Its Distance After Ukraine Secession Referendums
headline.print_headline: Russia Keeps Its Distance After Ukraine Secession Referendums
